Authors:
Azin Moslemi, Peter Ades, Tim Groom, Jason Barry Scott,
Marc E. Nicolas, Paul W.J. Taylor, Pedro W. Crous
Title:
Paraphoma chlamydocopiosa sp. nov. and Paraphoma pye sp.
nov., two new species associated with leaf and crown infection of
pyrethrum
Keywords:
bilocular pycnidia, longer conidia, Paraphoma
chlamydocopiosa, Paraphoma pye, pathogenicity, phylogenetic
analysis
Abstract:
Two new pathogens of pyrethrum, described as Paraphoma
chlamydocopiosa and Paraphoma pye, isolated from necrotic leaf lesions
on pyrethrum plants in northern Tasmania, Australia, were identified
using morphological characters, phylogenetic analysis of the internal
transcribed spacer (ITS), elongation factor 1-α (EF1-) and beta-tubulin
(TUB) genes, and pathogenicity bioassays. Bootstrap support in the
combined and individual gene region phylogenetic trees significantly
supported the two species that were significantly different from the
closely related P. chrysanthemicola and P. vinacea. Morphological
characteristics also supported the two new species, with conidia of P.
chlamydocopiosa being considerably longer and wider than either P.
chrysanthemicola or P. vinacea, and P. pye being distinct in forming
bilocular pycnidia. Glasshouse pathogenicity tests based on root dip
inoculation resulted in P. chlamydocopiosa and P. pye infecting the
crown and upper root tissues of pyrethrum plants, and significant
reduction in biomass two 2 months after inoculation. Both of these
Paraphoma spp. caused leaf lesions during in vitro and in vivo bioassays
two 2 weeks after foliar spray inoculation. Although P. chlamydocopiasa
and P. pye were shown to be crown rot pathogens, they also were commonly
isolated from leaves of diseased plants in pyrethrum fields of northern
Tasmania.
